## find() function

Returns the first element within context that matches the given selector(s).

**Signature:**

```typescript
declare function find<T extends Element = HTMLElement>(selectors: string, context?: Document | DocumentFragment | Element): null | T;
```

## Parameters

<table><thead><tr><th>

Parameter


</th><th>

Type


</th><th>

Description


</th></tr></thead>
<tbody><tr><td>

selectors


</td><td>

string


</td><td>

One or more selectors to match.


</td></tr>
<tr><td>

context


</td><td>

Document \| DocumentFragment \| Element


</td><td>

_(Optional)_ The context from which to search from.


</td></tr>
</tbody></table>

**Returns:**

null \| T

## Remarks

Unlike using `querySelector()`<!-- -->, the default inferred element type is `HTMLElement`<!-- -->, rather than `Element`<!-- -->. More often than not this is the preferred behaviour, so it saves having to explicitly type it.

## Example 1

Find an element using the entire document as context (default).

```ts
const element = find('.foo');
```

## Example 2

Find an element using another element as context.

```ts
const element = find('.foo', contextElement);
```

## Example 3

Infer the type of element using the generic `find<T>`<!-- -->.

```ts
const element = find<HTMLButtonElement>('.foo');
```
